intro: Commiphora hodai, commonly known as the Indian myrrh or Himalayan myrrh, is a small, deciduous tree native to the Himalayan regions of India and Nepal. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing plants. The tree produces a resinous sap that is tapped from its bark, which has been used traditionally for medicinal and aromatic purposes. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and have a leathery texture, while its flowers are small and inconspicuous. The plant is adapted to high-altitude environments and thrives in cool, moist climates.
